item.title: A simple * calcolator gone rong?
item.dc:creator: @iwasinmoparseas101cl iwasinmoparseas101class
item.description:
@iwasinmoparseas101cl wrote:

import java.util.*;
public class Calk
{
	public static void main(String[] agrs){
		int var1 = 0;
		int var2 = 0;
		int var3 = 0;
		Scanner input = new Scanner(System.in);
		System.out.println("I am a computer.  Ask me a times table question and I\'ll" +
				" answer it for you!");
 
		System.out.print("What\'s your starting number? ");
		var1 = input.nextInt();
 
		System.out.print("What number would you like it multiplied by? ");
		var2 = input.nextInt();
 
		var3 = var1 * var2;
 
		System.out.printf("The answer to your question is :  %d", var3);
	}
}

This works correctly. You could try storing the values as doubles or floats (whichever you prefer) and then use the String.format(String src, variable) method. It works like printf, but you’d store it as a String so:

String ans = String.format("3.2f", var3);
System.out.println("The answer is: " + ans);

On another topic

why are you using C’s function of printf? printstreams dont have a printf method if i recall correctly, and you would just do System.out.println(var1 * var2)

actually printf does exist here, and it works just like C++'s

System.out.printf("%d", String1);

String1 replaces %d
so if String1 would be xyzzy, printf would return “xyzzy”

and 1 sec, ill get your thing for you

ok, heres some much cleaner code, and will do decimal too XD

import java.util.Scanner;

public class Calc0r
{
	public static void main(String[] args)
	{

item.title: A simple * calcolator gone rong?
item.dc:creator: @bullzeye95 bullzeye
item.description:
@bullzeye95 wrote:

Instead of making them int’s, make them long’s. Try this: [code]import java.util.*;
/n00b1’s quick learning of java/

public class java
{
public static void main(String[] agrs)

{
	long var1 = 0;
	long var2 = 0;
	long var3 = 0;


	Scanner input = new Scanner(System.in);



	System.out.print("i am a computer ask me a times table question and ill anser it for you");

	System.out.print("whats your starting number?");
	var1 = input.nextInt();

	System.out.print("what number would you like it timesd by?");
	var2 = input.nextInt();

	input.close();

	var3 = var1 * var2;

	System.out.println("the anser to your question is "+ var3);

}

}
[/code]
You still can’t put 10 digits in, but you can put in 9.

item.title: A simple * calcolator gone rong?
item.dc:creator: @D27L7T D27L7T
item.description:
@D27L7T wrote:

Your code doesn’t actually multiply the numbers.

But I got it to compile.

//~--- JDK imports ------------------------------------------------------------

import java.util.*;

/*n00b1's quick learning of java*/

//~--- classes ----------------------------------------------------------------

public class Calk {
    public static void main(String[] agrs) {
        int var1 = 0;
        int var2 = 0;
        int var3 = 0;

        var3 = var1 * var2;

        Scanner input = new Scanner(System.in);

        System.out.print(
            "i am a computer ask me a times table question and ill anser it for you 
");
        System.out.print("whats your starting number?");
        var1 = input.nextInt();
        System.out.print("what number would you like it timesd by?");
        var2 = input.nextInt();
        input.close();
        System.out.printf(
            "the anser to your question is %d 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
",
            var3);
    }
}

I formatted it for you, but this honestly reminds me of C++ more than Java.[br][size=1]Posted at: October 29, 2006, 07:36:32 AM[/size][hr]Here we go, got it to work. You multiplied them while they were both zero, you have to actually multiply them after you give them values.

//~--- JDK imports ------------------------------------------------------------

import java.util.*;

/*n00b1's quick learning of java*/

//~--- classes ----------------------------------------------------------------

public class Calk {
    public static void main(String[] agrs) {
        int var1 = 0;
        int var2 = 0;
        int var3 = 0;

        Scanner input = new Scanner(System.in);

        System.out.print(
            "i am a computer ask me a times table question and ill anser it for you 
");
        System.out.print("whats your starting number?");
        var1 = input.nextInt();
        System.out.print("what number would you like it timesd by?");
        var2 = input.nextInt();
        input.close();
        var3 = var1 * var2;
        System.out.printf(
            "the anser to your question is %d 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
",
            var3);
    }
}
